journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part F: Journal of Rail and Rapid Transit

title-group.article-title: Long co-planar mode III fatigue crack growth under non-proportional mixed mode loading in rail steel

article-meta.aff: 1Vehicle Structure Technology Division, Railway Technical Research Institute, Japan

author-notes.corresp: Makoto Akama, Railway Technical Research Institute, 2-8-38, Hiari-cho, Kokubunji-shi,185-8540, Japan. Email: akama@rtri.or.jp

abstract.p: Fatigue tests have been performed to obtain the co-planar crack growth rate in rail steel under non-proportional mixed mode I and mode III cycles. In addition, a finite element analysis (FEA) has been performed to investigate the crack growth behaviour under this loading. The experiments showed that a long co-planar crack could be produced under this loading. Based on fracture surface observations obtained using a scanning electron microscope and FEA, the long co-planar crack growth was thought to be driven mainly by mode III loading and the role of mode I was as an assistant; keeping the crack face open. It was also observed that the crack tended to branch when the degree of overlap between the mode I and mode III cycles increased. Comparing the crack growth rate data under loading with that under non-proportional mixed mode I and II cycles, it was found that the co-planar growth rates were similar regardless of whether the main driving force was in-plane shear or out-of-plane shear.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Surface-breaking cracks in rails, sometimes called squats, under rolling contact fatigue (RCF) induced by wheel passage are subjected to complex sequential mixed-mode loading. For a period the crack propagates stably in the rail head at a shallow angle to the surface and at this point it is considered to be a co-planar crack growth. Several numerical stress intensity factor analyses of the three-dimensional (3D) surface-breaking cracks under RCF have been reported in the literature.

Murakami et al.1 examined the stress field around RCF crack tips for 3D models in an elastic half-space using the body force method. They analysed the variations of mode I and mode II stress intensity factors (KI and KII) at the deepest point of the crack front whereas the mode III stress intensity factor (KIII) was calculated at the crack mouth with and without hydraulic pressure action. Fully reversed KIII variations were obtained.

Bogdanski et al.2 analysed a 3D model of RCF cracking using finite element analysis (FEA). Their model considered the actual section of rail and wheel geometries where the wheel was rolling over the running band of the rail containing the squat crack. In their study, no fluid pressure action was taken into account and the effects of crack size, residual stress, the crack face friction and so on were examined. The distributions of KI, KII and KIII along the crack front for representative positions of the wheel were calculated. The complex variations of overlapped KI, KII and KIII were obtained with the value of KI being small compared with KII and KIII.

Bogdanski and Lewicki3 estimated the 3D crack front loading enhancements due to the action of the fluid entrapment mechanism using the iterative numerical procedure in FEA. The volume of fluid entrapped was determined on the basis of the 3D crack geometry for the position of the load, in which the leading edge of the contact patch was touching the crack mouth. In that study, fully reversed KII and KIII variations were obtained and the value of KI was comparable to that of KII and KIII. The cycles of KI and KIII, as well as that of KI and KII were overlapped about the same patterns.

There is an extensive literature that considers co-planar crack growth in rail steel for non-proportional mixed mode I and II loading cycles. Bold et al.4 performed fatigue tests where cyclic mode I and II loads were applied sequentially. Biaxial cruciform specimens made of rail steel were used in their experiments. When the mode I loading was applied and removed before the fully reversed mode II loading was applied, a long co-planar crack growth was produced for the cases where the ratio of the nominal value of KI range (ΔKI) to KII range (ΔKII) was greater than or equal to one-half.

In advancing the experiments performed by Bold et al.,4 Wong et al.5,6 carried out sequential mixed mode I and II loading experiments on cruciform specimens. If the mode II load is applied before the mode I load is removed, a degree of overlap (δ) appears. They considered the effective values of ΔKI and ΔKII (ΔKIeff and ΔKIIeff), and the effect of δ on the crack growth. Crack growth models were proposed in ΔKIeff and ΔKIIeff form. They found that ΔKIeff was a control parameter that determined the crack growth direction and that increasing δ encouraged cracks to branch. They also proposed the branch criterion in terms of ΔKIeff and δ.

Sequential mode I and mode II fatigue crack growth tests were performed on rail steel by Doquet and Pommier.7 They used tubular specimens and gold micro-grids with a 4 µm pitch that were laid ahead of crack tips and along the crack surfaces to observe the residual shifts. Hundreds of microns of constant speed co-planar growth were obtained when ΔKII/ΔKI ranged in value from one to four. They also conducted a FEA to investigate the role of plasticity and crack face friction. They concluded that the maximum growth rate criterion rationalized the crack path observed in the non-proportional loadings.

Akama and Susuki8 performed non-proportional mixed mode I and II fatigue growth tests on rail and wheel steel that were in practical use in Japan. Referring to the experiments performed by Wong et al.5,6 they produced crack growth models using ΔKIeff and ΔKIIeff. They found that cracks in wheel steel propagated quickly and were easy to branch compared with the case for rail steel. They also observed fracture surfaces but no clear striation patterns were found.

To clarify the incipient crack path direction observed in Bold et al.,4 Dahlin and Olsson9 investigated several criteria together using the FEA approach. They concluded that a maximum tangential stress range criterion considering an elasto-plastic stress field (MTSRp) was appropriate to predict the incipient crack growth direction in the ductile metal.

Compared with the numerous experiments on co-planar crack growth under non-proportional mixed mode I and II loading cycles that can be found in the literature, fatigue crack growth tests under non-proportional mixed mode I and III loading are rare. Surely, historically many experiments under proportional loading have been performed. Ritchie et al.10 investigated the direction of crack growth in AISI 4340 steel using circumferentially notched, torsional bar specimens subjected to fully reversed mode III loading both with and without superimposed static mode I loading. The fatigue fracture surface in pure mode III at high stress levels appeared flat and smeared and the preferred form of crack growth was by longitudinal mode II surface or lateral mode III cracks. In contrast, at longer crack length and lower torque levels, mode I cracks grew on planes at 45° to the specimen axis displaying a factory roof appearance.

In contrast, Nayeb-Hashemi et al.11 found no correlation between crack growth rate and KIII range (ΔKIII) or plastic strain intensity range (ΔΓIII) unless a static mode I load was superimposed on the mode III loading for a low-strength AISI 4140 steel. When this was done, the variability in crack growth rates was reduced.

Tschegg12 studied the effects of static mode I loads on mode III growth in AISI 1018 steel at constant ΔΓIII. Small mode I loads reduced the frictional effects of crack surface contact while above a critical KI, mode I branch crack was promoted and growth rates decreased.

Brown et al.13 applied reversed torsion with and without a superimposed end load to round bar specimens containing sharp notches made of 1%Cr-Mo-V steel. ΔKIII could not satisfactorily correlate all the crack growth data but ΔΓIII showed a significant improvement and provided a single upper bound solution for both ambient and elevated temperatures.

Liu et al.14 investigated the transition of fracture type under a mixed mode I and III loading condition. A criterion based on the competition of the maximum normal stress and maximum shear stress was utilized. They used circumferentially notched cylindrical specimen made of poly(methyl methacrylate) (PMMA) and 7050 aluminium alloy. Only the tensile fracture type was observed for PMMA whereas either tensile or shear type fracture occurred for aluminium alloy depending on the mode ratio.

Tarantino et al.15 performed mode III co-planar crack propagation tests in a bearing steel under mixed-mode loadings representing sub-surface RCF conditions. The results showed that the presence of a superimposed compression enhanced shear co-planar growth resulting in much lower mode III threshold values than for simple torsion. An analytical model was used to show that typical crack opening values caused by the out-of-phase loads prevented contact of the crack faces during the RCF load cycles.

It is clear from the presented literature review that experimental studies on squat cracks seem to concentrate on the growth under non-proportional mixed mode I and II loading although the mode III loading can generate at the crack tips simultaneously. Also, the fatigue crack growth tests for many structural steels under mixed mode I and III loading concentrate on proportional loadings. Therefore, in this study fatigue tests are performed to obtain the co-planar crack growth rate under non-proportional mixed mode I and mode III cycles that can simulate RCF conditions. Following completion of the test, a few specimens are broken and fatigue fracture surfaces are examined using a scanning electron microscope (SEM). In addition, FEA is performed to investigate the crack growth behaviour under the loading.

sec.title: Procedures
sec.p:
Non-proportional mixed mode I and III fatigue tests were conducted on circumferentially notched round bar specimens made of normal rail steel. Figure 1(a) shows the geometry of the specimen and Figure 1(b) the details of the notch that has a 30° groove, is 4.5 mm deep with a 0.1 mm root radius. The notch was inserted into the centre of the specimen using spark erosion. The chemical composition of normal rail steel is listed in Table 1. The monotonic yield stress and ultimate tensile strength of the steel are 508 MPa and 948 MPa, respectively. Figure 1.
Specimen used for the experiments (a) whole configuration and (b) details of the notch (all dimensions in millimetres). Table 1.
Composition in wt % of the studied rail steel.
C Si Mn P S
0.68 0.26 0.93 0.016 0.01

The tests were performed on a maximum 200 kN tension – compression force and fully reversed maximum torque of 1000 Nm servo-hydraulic testing machine under load control at a frequency of 1 Hz in dry condition. Four displacement gauges were set on the knife edges, which were attached across the notch on the surface of the specimen for the circumferential direction at every 90° to measure the compliance as shown in Figure 2. The specimen was mounted on the machine by adjusting the maximum difference of the four strains from the average within 5%, and then the test was performed. Figure 2.
Experimental setup showing the specimen with displacement gauge attached for the measurement of opening displacements.

The loading history is similar to that experienced by RCF cracks obtained from FEA2,3 and one loading cycle is shown in Figure 3. A personal computer was used to both control the testing machine by generating the non-proportional loading cycles and also to record readings from the displacement gauges for the calculation of the crack depth. Figure 3.
One applied loading cycle. This figure shows the condition of ΔKIII/ΔKI = 1.5 and δ = 90°.

The crack depths were calculated using the compliance technique. Consider a circumferentially cracked bar, which is subjected to an axial force P as shown in Figure 4. The relationship between energy release rate G and compliance λ can be expressed as (1)G=P22dλdA where A is the area of the crack. G can also be expressed in terms of KI as follows (2)G=KI2E' (3)E'={Eplane stressE(1-ν2)plane strain where E is the Young’s modulus ( = 206 GPa) and ν is Poisson’s ratio ( = 0.3). Considering the crack depth c ( = b – a) and its increment dc in Figure 4 (4)dA=2aπdc=-2abπd(ab) where a and b are the current net radius and outer radius of the bar specimen, respectively. Hence (5)λ=∫0A2KI2E'P2dA=-∫1x4abπKI2E'P2dx where x denotes a/b. Figure 4.
Circumferentially cracked bar that is subjected to an axial force P.
In this case, KI can be expressed as the following equation16 (6)

Substituting equation (6) into equation (5) and neglecting the higher-order terms in x, the compliance λ (considering also the stretch of specimen) is obtained as (7)λ=δcP=[L/πb-F(x)]E'b where δc is the opening displacement of the gauge due to P and L is the gauge length (see Figure 1). F(x) is denoted by (8)

Calculations of the value of KI and KIII were performed by the following equations16 (9)KI=Pπa2π(b-a)f(x) (10)KIII=2Taπa3π(b-a)g(x) where Ta is the applied torque. The functions f(x) and g(x) can be expressed as (11)f(x)=12x(1+12x+38x2-0.363x3+0.731x4) (12)

Crack growth rates were calculated using the incremental polynominal method. This method involves fitting a second-order polynomial to sets of five successive data points. Pre-cracking was not performed; instead the growth data within 0.7 mm from notch tip were discarded.

Experiments were performed by using four specimens that are referred to as RP1, RP2, RP3 and RP4, respectively. Table 2 shows the ratios of ΔKIII to ΔKI (ΔKIII/ΔKI) and δ for each experiment. For all the experiments, the stress ratio of mode I (RI) and that of mode III (RIII) were 0.05 and -1, respectively. Table 2.
Loading conditions.
Experiment ΔKIII/ΔKI δ (deg)
RP1 1.5 90
RP2 1.5 30, 120
RP3 1.0 90, 30
RP4 1.5 180

Experiments RP1, RP2 and RP3 were intended to mainly produce co-planar crack growth rate data, whereas branch crack growth rate data were obtained in experiment RP4. After the crack depth had extended to about a half of the diameter of the specimen, δ was changed in experiments RP2 and RP3.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The co-planar crack grew almost straight for all of δ in experiments RP1 and RP3. In the experiment RP2, the co-planar crack branched when δ was changed to 120°. In contrast, when δ was 180°, branch cracking occurred and propagated in experiment RP4 making the fracture associated with ridges and valleys, termed as a factory-roof fracture.

sec.title: Co-planar crack growth rates
sec.p:
Co-planar crack growth rates are plotted against ΔKI in Figure 5 that also includes pure mode I growth data, which was done at RI = 0.1, for comparison. The fatigue crack growth rates in mixed mode I and III appear to be quicker than the corresponding rates in pure mode I. When a Paris-type law is applied to the crack growth rates for all the mixed mode data, the following equation is obtained (13)dcdN=2.11×10-8(ΔKI)3.31(R2=0.52) where N is the number of cycles and R2 is the R-squared value. Figure 5.
Co-planar crack growth rates against mode I stress intensity ranges comparing pure mode I data.

The crack growth rates are plotted against ΔKIII in Figure 6. In this case, the data on crack growth rates are summarized by the following equation (14)dcdN=4.68×10-8(ΔKIII)2.64(R2=0.82) Figure 6.
Co-planar crack growth rates against mode III stress intensity ranges.

Finally, the crack growth rates are plotted against equivalent stress intensity factor range ΔKeq in Figure 7. ΔKeq can be defined as (15)ΔKeq=ΔKI2+ΔKIII2 Figure 7.
Co-planar crack growth rates against equivalent stress intensity ranges.
The crack growth rates can be expressed as (16)dcdN=4.72×10-9(ΔKeq)3.03 (R2=0.80)

Overall, it is seen that: when δ is the same, the crack growth rates become greater due to the increase of ΔKIII/ΔKI and if the ΔKIII/ΔKI is the same, the growth rates become faster due to the increase of δ.

sec.title: Branch crack growth rates
sec.p:
When δ is equal to 180°, a branch crack propagation took place for ΔKIII/ΔKI = 1.5. Figure 8 shows the branch crack growth rates against ΔKeq comparing with a co-planar growth rate. It can be seen that the branch crack growth rates are about seven to 10 times slower than the co-planar growth rates. Figure 8.
Mixed mode I and III crack growth rates against equivalent stress intensity ranges comparing co-planar and branch crack growth.

sec.title: Fractography
sec.p:
Macroscopic observations of the fracture surface are shown in Figure 9. The surface of RP1 is macroscopically flat whereas that of RP4 indicates factory-roof fracture. Figure 9.
Macroscopic fracture surfaces. (a) RP1 (ΔKIII/ΔKI = 1.5, δ = 90°), (b) RP4 (ΔKIII/ΔKI = 1.5, δ = 180°).

The fracture surfaces were then more thoroughly observed using a SEM and micrographs of them are shown in Figure 10. In the literature10 it is reported that pure mode III experiments where the growth rates were high and crack lengths were short resulted in a fracture surface that was flat and smeared out, with evidence of severe rubbing, abrasion and fretting oxide formation. In contrast, for the case of RP1 in this study, there is no evidence of the contact of crack faces and fretting debris and oxide generated from the surface are hardly seen. This suggests that the attenuation by the surface friction was quite limited. As reported by previous studies for mixed mode I and II loading6,7 no striation was found in this study. This is not a consequence of wearing by the mating crack faces because the crack face contact did not occurred. Figure 10.
Fracture surface of RP1 observed using a SEM (a) at low magnification (arrow indicates the direction of the crack propagation and the square in the figure indicates the region shown in (b) and (b) a high-magnification image of the square region.

sec.title: Procedures
sec.p:
Elasto-plastic 3D FEA was performed using the commercial code ADINA. The analyses were performed at the loading condition of ΔKIII/ΔKI = 1.5 and δ = 30°, 90°, 120° and 180° to investigate the effect of δ on crack growth direction. The mesh and the deformed shapes under various positions of the loading cycle are shown in Figure 11. It is believed that plasticity is highly localized to the vicinity of the notch under the loading and other regions of the specimen remain elastic. Therefore, only the region near the symmetry section for the axial direction was required to be included in the mesh. The crack depth c was modelled as 4.6 mm for the case of δ = 30°, 90° and 180° whereas for δ = 120° it was 7 mm representing the actual test conditions. The density of the mesh became higher closer to the crack tip and the size of the eight-node brick element at the crack tip was 100 µm, which is believed to be sufficient to include the plastic zone ahead of the crack tip. The total number of elements and nodes were 14,001 and 15,522, respectively. Figure 11.
Finite element mesh for circumferentially notched round bar specimen and deformations (ΔKIII/ΔKI = 1.5 and δ = 90°): (a) applied loads and boundary conditions; (b) maximum deformation by mode I loading; and (c) maximum deformation by mode III loading. Note that in (b) and (c), the magnifications are both × 1000. RTZ represents the global cylindrical coordinate system whose origin coincides with specimen centre O.

When analysing the fatigue problem, the choice of the material constitutive model is important. In this study, a model that combined a non-linear kinematic hardening rule with the isotropic hardening rule developed by Chaboche and Lemaitre17 (C&L model) was employed (17)ti+Δtiσy=0σy+Q[1-exp(-B×ti+Δtie¯p)] (18)dα=23hdep-ζαde¯p where ti+Δtiσy is the updated yield stress at time ti + Δti, 0σy is the initial yield stress, Q and B the material constants, ti+Δtie¯p the accumulated effective plastic strain at ti + Δti, α the shift of the centre of the yield surface, ep the plastic strain, h and ζ are material constants and d implies increment. The material constants were determined by strain-controlled uniaxial fatigue experiments using normal rail steel as follows Q=-208MPa, B=24.2,h=85248MPa, ζ=193

The force P and torque Ta were applied to the centre node of the rigid element that was constructed with all the nodes on the upper surface of the mesh. ΔP was equal to 55 kN (RI = 0.05) and ΔTa = 525 Nm (RIII = −1), respectively, that were the actual test conditions. The fixed boundary conditions applied on the lower surface of the mesh were those of the symmetry condition for the axial direction.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: When the C&L model was used, lots of loading cycles are needed to achieve a steady state stress cycle. Therefore, the first, 10th, 100th and 160th cycles were simulated to understand the convergence of the stress state. The results show that, for example, the differences in the maximum normal stress during one loading cycle on the symmetry plane for the axial direction in the crack tip element between the first and 10th, 10th and 100th, 100th and 160th cycles were 18.5, 19.1 and 0.4%, respectively. Therefore, the evaluations were performed within 160 loading cycles.

sec.title: Plane of maximum normal stress range and that of maximum shear stress range
sec.p:
Dahlin and Olsson9 suggested that the MTSRp criterion can capture the effect of δ on crack branching in rail steel. This criterion says that the crack deviation angle is along the material plane on which the normal stress range Δσ is a maximum during the time period of the selected load cycle. The Δσ level on every plane was investigated in this study. When the normal stress was less than zero, it was reset to zero in the calculation. Such a plane was expressed by θ, φ and ψ that are the rotation angles around the R, T and Z axes of the local cylindrical coordinate system whose origin coincides with the centre of the crack tip element. Note that the order of the rotation was first θ, then φ and finally ψ. These are depicted in Figure 12 for clarity. The rotations were performed for every 1° for each axis. Figure 12.
Branch cracks at a main crack and definition of local cylindrical coordinate system RTZ.

In addition, the shear stress range Δτ on every plane was also searched. The underlying assumption was that if the cracks grew by a shear mode, the growth direction should be determined by the shear stress range near the crack tip. Δτ was represented by a range of ΔτZT values because under the adopted loading condition, ΔτZR was thought to be small. The results of the calculation show that the maximum value of ΔτZR was at most about one-fifth of that of ΔτZT during the loading cycle.

The variations of Δσ and Δτ due to θ for the different values of δ during the 160th loading cycle are depicted on the φ = ψ = 0 plane in Figure 13. The absolute values of the stresses depend on the distance from the crack tip so they are not important. Therefore, Δσ and Δτ at each position θ were divided by the larger value of the maximum Δσ and Δτ (Δσmax and Δτmax), which was Δτmax in all cases. It is shown that when δ increases, the relative value of Δσ increases and the Δσmax plane turns towards the branch direction whereas the Δτmax plane remains on the co-planar plane. In the actual calculation results, both Δσmax and Δτmax planes were identified to be also slightly oriented to the φ direction within 7° for all cases. Figure 13.
Shear stress range and normal stress range at each angle θ (ΔKIII/ΔKI = 1.5, RI = 0.05, RIII = −1).

sec.title: Crack opening displacement
sec.p:
The situation of the crack face contact is important because it can possibly influence the crack path direction. It has been suggested that rubbing is the reason for the termination of the growth of fatigue cracks. Therefore, the results of the FEA were used to clarify the crack opening displacement (COD). Figure 14 shows the variations of the COD at several nodes behind the crack tip during the first, 10th, 100th and 160th loading cycles. These did not fall to zero during the mode III part of the cycle and they gradually increased. Figure 14.
Development of crack opening displacement behind the crack tip (ΔKIII/ΔKI = 1.5, δ = 90°, RI = 0.05, RIII = −1).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Fatigue tests were performed to obtain the co-planar crack growth rate under non-proportional mixed mode I and mode III cycles that can simulate RCF conditions. The growth rates were arranged by ΔKI, ΔKIII and ΔKeq, and a relatively good correlation was obtained by ΔKIII. When arranging by ΔKI, they were almost 10 times faster than for under pure mode I loading. These facts highlight that the crack propagation rates have a relatively strong dependence on ΔKIII. They were also compared with the branch crack growth rate that occurred by increasing δ. In this case, the co-planar crack growth rates were faster than the branch crack growth rate by an order of magnitude.

There was no evidence in the SEM observations to support crack face contact and this was confirmed by the FEA. It has been suggested that rubbing is the reason for the termination of the fatigue crack growth. In this study, no rubbing effects were observed between the faces of the crack. The crack faces were opened during the tests partly as a result of a positive stress ratio and partly by plastic ratchetting. When the crack face contacts with its mating face and the friction attenuates mode III loading, the crack is usually arrested. If contact does not take place, it becomes possible to produce a long shear mode crack.

The planes that experienced Δσmax and Δτmax were investigated by FEA. The result of the FEA suggested that the co-planar growth, occurred in the experiment when δ = 30° or 90°, was in the plane of Δτmax. If mode I loading was the main driving force for the crack to grow, the cracks extended to the direction that experienced Δσmax. Because the crack grew in the Δτmax direction and traces of striation could not be observed on the plane, it can be suggested that the crack growth was mainly driven by an out-of-plane shear mode. The main role of mode I loading was considered to be to separate the crack faces so that the crack was not arrested.

An increasing δ resulted in an increasing Δσmax relative to Δτmax and Δσmax turned to the branch direction, whereas Δτmax remained on the co-planar direction. The widely accepted criterion to predict the crack growth direction under non-proportional loading is that the crack selects to grow along the fastest growth rate direction.18 To date, the exact solution for a co-planar main crack with a branch crack at 45° to the main crack plane in a round bar specimen has not yet been proposed. Therefore, quantitative evaluations about the growth direction cannot be performed. However, as the co-planar crack growth rates have a relatively strong dependence on ΔKIII, it should also be for Δτ, and branch crack growth rates are generally considered to have a relation with Δσ, it is appropriate to interpret that the crack is apt to branch when δ increases.

Akama and Susuki8 performed non-proportional mixed mode I and II fatigue growth tests on the same rail steel under similar loading cycles as this study. Co-planar crack growth rates under mode I and II arranged by ΔKIIeff were compared with those under mode I and III arranged by ΔKIII in this study. The result is shown in Figure 15. The data for mode I and II loading includes the conditions of ΔKII/ΔKI = 1.0, 1.5 and δ is changed from 0° to 90° in steps of 10°. As shown in the previous section, the crack faces in the present study are always open; therefore, ΔKIII can be taken to be the effective values. In Figure 15, although the variance is relative large, almost the same growth rates are obtained which implies that when co-planar growth assisted by mode I occurs, the growth rates are about the same regardless of whether the main driving force is in-plane shear or out–of-plane shear. Garnham et al.19 improved the two-and-a-half dimensional stress intensity factor calculation method to investigate the effect of lateral traction. This modelling approach uses 3D stress field and two-dimensional Greens functions; therefore, it can predict KI and KII but not KIII. The present results can help to discuss the validity of the method and to improve it further. Figure 15.
Comparison of the co-planar crack growth rates between mode I - mode III loading and mode I - mode II loading.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p:
Fatigue tests were performed to obtain the co-planar crack growth rate under non-proportional mixed mode I and mode III cycles. In addition, FEA was performed to investigate the crack growth behaviour. The results can be summarized as follows.
Experiments showed that a long co-planar crack could be produced under non-proportional mixed mode I and III loading that was considered to be similar to what is sometimes observed in experiments under non-proportional mixed mode I and II loading.
Under the same ratio of ΔKIII/ΔKI, the co-planar crack growth rates were faster than the branch crack growth rate by an order of magnitude.
Based on the fracture surface observations by SEM and FEA, the long co-planar crack growth was thought to be driven mainly by mode III loading and the role of mode I was an assistant; it kept the crack face open.
An increasing δ resulted in an increasing Δσmax relative to Δτmax and the plane of Δσmax turned towards the branch direction. As the branch crack growth rates were generally considered to be related with the tangential stress range, it was appropriate to interpret that the crack tended to branch when δ increased.
Comparing the co-planar crack growth rates data under non-proportional mixed mode I and III loading with that under non-proportional mixed mode I and II loading for the same rail steel, it was found that the growth rates were similar regardless of whether the main driving force was in-plane shear or out-of-plane shear.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This study was performed as a part of the research and development programme for the future of railways, ‘Creation of rail damage/ballast track deterioration models and evaluation of maintenance work saving technologies’ at the Railway Technical Research Institute. The first author would like to acknowledge the financial support and encouragement received from this project.
